metadata.case_name: Venkateswara Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh & Ors.

facts.text: Government of Andhra Pradesh initiated Community Development Programme, dividing each district into Community Development Blocks including Chintalapudi Taluk in West Godavari District. Block Planning and Development Committee appointed for each Block.

On March 22, 1957, Government issued notification laying down principles for location of Primary Health Centres, including village to give 2 acres of site free and cash contribution not less than Rs. 10,000/-
On April 8, 1958, Block Planning and Development Committee, Chintalapudi, unanimously resolved to have Primary Health Centre at Dharmajigudem due to High Schools and education facilities.
On November 7, 1958, Collector inaugurated Primary Health Centre at Dharmajigudem.

On July 11, 1959, Block Committee passed resolution appreciating donation of 50 cents land by Achyutharamaiah and appealing for Rs. 10,000/- cash; later same meeting resolved to shift Centre if contribution not paid in 8 months.
On July 13, 1959, Block Development Officer wrote to appellant (President of Dharmajigudem Panchayat) that no steps taken for contribution and would shift if not realized by month end.
On July 16, 1959, appellant and others informed Block Development Officer impossible to collect amount, no objection to shifting.
On July 17, 1959, Block Development Officer informed Dharmajigudem that Centre would be shifted to Lingapalem.
On July 27, 1959, 4th respondent Rangarao deposited Rs. 10,000/- and donated 2 acres for Lingapalem.
On July 31, 1959, appellant on behalf of Dharmajigudem deposited Rs. 10,000/-; K. Krishna Rao donated 2 acres and delivered possession.
On August 14, 1959, Block Committee unanimously resolved to locate Primary Health Centre permanently at Lingapalem, noting Dharmajigudem representatives assured agreement and gave up efforts.
On September 18, 1959, Andhra Pradesh Panchayat Samithis and Zilla Parishads Act, 1959 came into force; Panchayat Samithi constituted for Chintalapudi.
On January 7, 1960, Government informed Collector to leave shifting decision to Panchayat Samithi and place August 14, 1959 resolution for reconsideration.
On May 28, 1960, Panchayat Samithi resolved Primary Health Centre permanently at Dharmajigudem.
On July 6, 1960, Government approved Panchayat Samithi proposal to locate at Dharmajigudem.
On January 23, 1961, Rules under s.69 of Act came into force.
On February 22, 1961, Government decided not to interfere with May 28, 1960 meeting under s.72 due to inadequate notice allegation.
On May 12, 1961, Panchayat Samithi at special meeting cancelled all resolutions of May 28, 1960 under r.15 as not in accordance with r.4(1).
On May 29, 1961, Panchayat Samithi adopted cancelled resolutions except location, resolved to locate at Lingapalem.
On March 7, 1962, Government ordered no valid reason to shift from Dharmajigudem (already functioning), resolution lacked 2/3 majority under rules; directed Block Development Officer accordingly.
On April 18, 1963, Government reviewed March 7 order under s.72, held mistaken impression of permanent location at Dharmajigudem; directed permanent location at Lingapalem per May 29 resolution.

Appellant filed writ petition under Art.226 in Andhra Pradesh High Court seeking certiorari to quash April 18, 1963 order; dismissed by single Judge; confirmed by Division Bench on September 7, 1964 in Writ Appeal No.8 of 1964.
Appellant is President of Dharmajigudem Panchayat, formed committee, collected and deposited Rs.10,000/-, represented village throughout.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant had locus standi to file writ petition under Art.226.
Whether Government order dated March 7, 1962 was under s.62 or s.72 of the Act, and could it be reviewed under s.72.
Whether review order April 18, 1963 valid: prerequisite of mistake satisfied, and opportunity of representation given.
Whether impugned order made under Rules under s.69 r/w s.18(2), vesting ultimate authority in Government.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of March 7, 1962 cancelling resolution of May 29, 1961 made under s.62, cannot be reviewed under s.72.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.62, s.72 Andhra Pradesh Panchayat Samithis and Zilla Parishads Act, 1959

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if under s.72(1), review order April 18, 1963 invalid as no mistake of fact/law or ignorance of material fact.
Review order invalid as no opportunity given to prejudiced party to make representation.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant has no personal right or locus standi under Art.226.
March 7, 1962 order was composite direction under s.72(1), reviewable under s.72(3) due to mistake.
Even if under s.62, administrative order reviewable under s.62 on discovery of mistake.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.62; s.13 Madras General Clauses Act

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned order not under s.62 or s.72 but under Rules under s.69 r/w s.18(2), Government has ultimate authority to locate PHC.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant has locus standi as representative of village committee which collected/deposited funds as trustees; prejudiced by order; can file under Art.226 even without proprietary interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Personal right can be trustee interest; exceptional cases for those prejudicially affected.

court_reasoning.text: Rules making Panchayat Samithi recommendatory only inconsistent with Act vesting power in Samithi under s.18(1),(2) Schedule (establish/maintain PHC); rules ultra vires to extent they transfer power to Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt cannot by rules convert statutory authority into recommendatory body.

court_reasoning.text: March 7, 1962 order was cancellation of May 29 resolution under s.62 (special power), not s.72 (general); cannot be reviewed under s.72(3) which applies only to s.72(1) orders. Also violated s.62(2) no notice to Samithi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Generals do not derogate from specials.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot sustain April 18 order under s.62 as quasi-judicial, functus officio post order; no review power unlike s.72.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.13 General Clauses Act inapplicable to quasi-judicial powers.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming under s.72, mistake of fact existed (no permanent location at Dharmajigudem as conditions not complied pre-Act, later resolution cancelled); but no notice to prejudiced appellant/representatives violating proviso s.72(1).
Both Govt orders illegal, but quashing April 18 would restore illegal March 7 order contrary to valid Samithi resolution for Lingapalem; HC rightly refused discretionary interference under Art.226.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equity: Centre never permanently at Dharmajigudem.

holdings.text: Appellant has locus standi under Art.226 as trustee representative prejudiced by order.
Rules under s.69 ultra vires to extent depriving Panchayat Samithi of location power under s.18.
March 7, 1962 order under s.62, not reviewable under s.72; violated s.62(2) notice.
April 18, 1963 review order invalid: no power to review s.62 order; even if s.72, no notice to prejudiced party.
High Court rightly exercised discretion not to quash April 18 order to avoid restoring illegal March 7 order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company (Proprietary) Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Locus standi under Art.226: wide power, not limited to fundamental rights; ordinarily personal/individual right, but can be trustee interest or for prejudicially affected.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Panchayat Samithis and Zilla Parishads Act, 1959 (Act No. XXXV of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting power to establish/maintain PHC in Panchayat Samithi; Govt power to cancel resolutions (s.62), revise/review (s.72); rules under s.69.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction for enforcing legal rights; locus standi.

statutes_cited.name: Rules for establishment and maintenance of Primary Health Centres by Panchayat Samithis (under s.69)
statutes_cited.relevance: Held ultra vires to extent making Samithi recommendatory; requirements for shifting/location.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Clauses Act, 1891
statutes_cited.relevance: Power exercisable from time to time; inapplicable to quasi-judicial s.62.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held both Government orders illegal but affirmed High Court's refusal to quash April 18, 1963 order under Art.226 discretion, as quashing would restore equally illegal March 7, 1962 order contrary to Panchayat Samithi's valid final resolution for Lingapalem.

key_quotes.text: "The right that can be enforced under Art. 226 also shall ordinarily be the personal or individual right of the petitioner himself, though in the case of some of the writs like habeas corpus or quo warranto this rule may have to be relaxed or modified."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines locus standi under Art.226, applied to grant standing to appellant.

key_quotes.text: "It cannot, by any rule, vest in itself a power which under the Act vests in another body."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds rules ultra vires for usurping Samithi's statutory power.

key_quotes.text: "The principle generalia specialibus non derogant compels us to exclude from the operation of s.72 the case provided for under s.62."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why s.62 order not reviewable under s.72.
